Award.AwardTitle: Exploratory Research to Demonstrate the Feasibility of "Tactile Internet" Islands

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The vision of this exploratory project is to support the research needed to examine the hardware-software techniques that would be needed to enable a Tactile Internet. The Tactile Internet is a wireless based internet framework for steering and control of remote objects and has the potential for breakthrough technologies much in the same way the cellular telephony was enabled by the wireless technologies during the past few decades. It could have wide ranging applications with broad social impact in areas such as education, traffic control, remote surgery, sports, entertainment, gaming, smart grid etc. Thus, the broader societal impact of the project would be in the long run, but is likely to be far reaching.


The project will develop novel algorithms and the hardware-software co-design methods to address the issues of ultra-low latency and resilience that would be required of the Tactile Internets of the future. The project will undertake building a prototype at the International Institute of Computer Science (ICSI) at Berkeley, California. It is expected that while the technical risks in this project are significant, the potential gains far exceed the risks, and if successful, this exploratory project can lead to new research more suitable for consideration by several federal and industrial sponsors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For the realization of the Tactile Internet Islands, a low latency of communications systems has to be guaranteed. In particular, for the wireless link this requires at most 100µs latency. For typical internet as well as control/cyber physical systems with packet sizes of 1500 Bytes this results in requiring very high data rates, clearly above 10 Gb/s per wireless link, which cannot be achieved with legacy solutions in communications systems as they are not designed for low-latency communication.

Within the project, the following two main goals were examined to meet the latency requirements: I) low-power high-speed communications and II) mm-wave technology advancement. Achievement for goal I): The power consumption of a transceiver system at 10 Gb/s data rates is dominated by the analog-to-digital converter (ADC). To circumvent the problem of the high ADC energy consumption a 1-bit quantization and an oversampling of the received signal can be considered. Studies within the project have demonstrated that oversampling allows to partly compensate the rate loss due to 1-bit quantization. Further theoretical investigations on the capacity of the time continuous 1-bit-quanitized channel have been carried out. An upper and a lower bound on the mutual information rate of the bandlimited continuous-time 1-bit quantized AWGN channel for a specific transmit waveform have been obtained, giving insight into the general behavior of such a system. These bounds show that approximately 1.5bit/s/Hz are achievable on a real channel, significantly outperforming the 1bit/s/Hz achievable without oversampling. Achievements for goal II): To achieve 10 Gb/s and beyond data rates at a low power consumption it is necessary to consume more than 1GHz of bandwidth. Such large bandwidth is available at mm-wave frequency which were exploited within this project, in particular at 60 GHz carrier frequency and beyond. To achieve reasonable transmit power limitations it is necessary at mm-wave frequencies to achieve significant antenna gains at the transmitter as well as the receiver. Solutions based on Butler matrices together with novel concepts for spatial windowing of antenna sizing has been developed that demonstrated significant gains of beam separation. In addition, novel waveform and frame structures for mm-wave frequencies have been developed together with hybrid beamforming and beam tracking algorithms to achieve the anticipated performance for Tactile Internet Island.

The outcomes of both goals have been demonstrated in a Tomahawk-4 platform enabling the investigation and implementation of low-latency high-bandwidth algorithms and in a large number of scientific publications.
